conclusion: Shadows are created when an object blocks part of the light source, and the light that is not blocked is cast onto a surface, forming a shadow.
When the light source moves upward, the angle at which the light hits the objects will decrease, causing shadows to be cast at a shallower angle relative to the objects.
Shadows will move closer to the objects and become shorter because the light has to travel a shorter distance to reach the ground after being blocked by the objects.
The size of the shadow is directly related to the angle at which the light hits the objects; when the light source is higher, the angle of incidence decreases, and the shadow will be smaller.
The light has to travel a longer path to reach the ground after being blocked by the objects, resulting in a smaller projection of the object's shape on the ground.
